projects.description: A command-line calculator that performs basic arithmetic operations using Java. Great for learning methods, input handling, and loops.

tasks.description: Setup Your Project Environment in the Basic Calculator project.

steps.description: Set up your project file to begin coding your calculator.
guidelines: Open an IDE or editor like IntelliJ or VS Code.
Create a new file and name it Calculator.java.
Include a main method inside the class.
why: This is your main program file that will contain the calculator logic.

tasks.description: Create Operation Methods in the Basic Calculator project.

steps.description: Create a reusable method for adding two numbers.
guidelines: Use 'public static' to define a method called add.
Pass two parameters and return their sum.
why: Creating functions helps modularize your code.

steps.step_name: Add Methods for Subtract, Multiply, Divide
steps.description: Add the other operations: subtraction, multiplication, and division.
guidelines: Use the same structure as the add method.
Ensure division method handles division by zero.
why: Each operation should have separate logic to keep code clean.

tasks.description: Take Input from User in the Basic Calculator project.

steps.description: Get two numbers and an operation from the user.
guidelines: Import java.util.Scanner.
Use Scanner to read numbers and operation from console.
why: Takes real-time input from user making it interactive.
steps.starting_code:
Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in);
System.out.print("Enter first number: ");

tasks.description: Perform Operation Based on Input in the Basic Calculator project.

steps.description: Use if/else to select the operation based on user input.
guidelines: Compare input char with +, -, *, / using if-else.
Call the corresponding method and display result.
why: Adds conditional logic to execute proper operation.

tasks.description: Loop Until User Exits in the Basic Calculator project.

steps.step_name: Add While Loop and Exit Option
steps.description: Wrap logic in a loop to keep calculator running until user quits.
guidelines: Use while(true) and ask user at end if they want to continue.
Use break to exit if user enters 'no'.
why: Improves usability by supporting multiple operations in one run.

projects.description: Build a console-based system to manage student records using Java. Learn OOP, collections, and input handling.

tasks.description: Setup Project Structure in the Student Management System project.

steps.description: Create the entry point of the application with a main method.
guidelines: Open your IDE and create a file named StudentManagementSystem.java.
Add a class and the main method inside it.
why: You need a main method to run any Java application.

steps.description: Add import statements for collections and scanner.
guidelines: You’ll use Scanner for input and ArrayList to store students.
Add imports at the top of your main class.
why: These packages provide necessary utilities for I/O and data management.
steps.starting_code: // import java.util.*;
steps.final_code:
import java.util.Scanner;
import java.util.ArrayList;

tasks.description: Create the Student Class in the Student Management System project.

steps.description: Create fields for student ID, name, email, and grade.
guidelines: Use appropriate data types.
Make fields public for simplicity (or private with getters/setters).
why: Encapsulates student information in a single object.

steps.description: Initialize all attributes and return student info as a string.
guidelines: Create a constructor with all fields as parameters.
Override the toString() method for readable output.
why: Constructors help easily create objects and toString improves output readability.
steps.starting_code: // public Student(...) { }

tasks.description: Store and Manage Data in the Student Management System project.

steps.description: Create an ArrayList to hold student objects.
guidelines: Use static ArrayList<Student> if methods are static.
Initialize it at class level.
why: Provides dynamic storage of student data.
steps.starting_code: // static ArrayList<Student> students;
steps.final_code: static ArrayList<Student> students = new ArrayList<>();

steps.description: Manually add a few students to test setup.
guidelines: Create new Student objects and add them to the list.
Print list contents to verify.
why: Verifies your Student class and list setup are correct.
steps.starting_code: // students.add(new Student(...));
steps.final_code:
students.add(new Student(1, "Alice", "alice@email.com", 92.5));
students.add(new Student(2, "Bob", "bob@email.com", 85.0));

tasks.description: Add Student Functionality in the Student Management System project.

steps.description: Ask user to enter student details using Scanner.
guidelines: Use nextInt, nextLine, and nextDouble methods of Scanner.
Be careful with newlines after int inputs.
why: You need dynamic input to make the system useful.
steps.starting_code: // Prompt user for input using Scanner

steps.step_name: Create Object and Add to List
steps.description: Use input to create a new Student and add to the list.
guidelines: Pass inputs to the constructor and call add().
why: Adds actual student data to your system.
steps.starting_code: // students.add(new Student(...));
steps.final_code: students.add(new Student(id, name, email, grade));

tasks.description: View Student Records in the Student Management System project.

steps.description: Handle case when there are no students in the list.
guidelines: Use students.isEmpty() before iterating.
why: Improves UX by avoiding empty output loops.
steps.starting_code: // if (students.isEmpty())

steps.description: Loop through the list and print each student.
guidelines: Use enhanced for-loop to iterate.
why: Displays student information to the user.
steps.starting_code: // for (Student s : students) { }

projects.description: Create a 2-player console-based Tic-Tac-Toe game in Java to practice arrays, game logic, input validation, and control structures.

tasks.description: Set Up the Game Board in the Tic-Tac-Toe project.

steps.description: Create a 2D char array and fill it with dashes.
guidelines: Use a 3x3 char array to represent the board.
Initialize all positions to '-'.
why: This is the core data structure for the game.
steps.starting_code: char[][] board = new char[3][3];

steps.step_name: Create a Function to Print the Board
steps.description: Write a method that prints the board in a readable format.
guidelines: Use nested loops to print the board state.
Include spaces or bars to separate cells.
why: Allows players to see the board after every move.

tasks.description: Player Move System in the Tic-Tac-Toe project.

steps.description: Use Scanner to prompt the current player for row and column input.
guidelines: Prompt user for row and column (0–2).
Read input using Scanner.
why: Takes move input from players.
steps.starting_code:
Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in);
System.out.print("Enter row and column: ");

steps.description: Ensure the selected cell is empty. If not, ask again.
guidelines: Check if board[row][col] == '-'.
Loop until valid input is received.
why: Prevents overwriting already played cells.

tasks.description: Add Game Mechanics in the Tic-Tac-Toe project.

steps.description: Alternate between player 'X' and player 'O'.
guidelines: Use a variable `currentPlayer`.
Flip between 'X' and 'O' after every turn.
why: Implements turn-based logic.
steps.starting_code: char currentPlayer = 'X';
steps.final_code: currentPlayer = (currentPlayer == 'X') ? 'O' : 'X';

steps.step_name: Track Total Moves and Detect Draw
steps.description: End the game in a draw if total moves reach 9.
guidelines: Initialize a move counter and increment each valid turn.
After 9 moves, if no win, it's a draw.
why: Ensures game terminates in case of a draw.
steps.starting_code: int moves = 0;

tasks.description: Check for Win Conditions in the Tic-Tac-Toe project.

steps.description: Check if the current player has won by completing a row, column, or diagonal.
guidelines: Loop through rows and columns to check equality.
Check both diagonals explicitly.
why: This decides the winner of the game.

steps.description: If `checkWin` returns true, end the game and announce the winner.
guidelines: After each move, call checkWin() with the current player.
If true, break the game loop.
why: Handles the game-ending condition.

tasks.description: Add Replay Option in the Tic-Tac-Toe project.

steps.step_name: Ask to Replay After Game Ends
steps.description: Prompt users if they want to play again. Reset the board if yes.
guidelines: Use Scanner to ask yes/no.
Reinitialize the board and counters if yes.
why: Improves user experience by allowing multiple games.
steps.starting_code: System.out.print("Play again? (yes/no): ");

projects.description: Build a console-based Library Management System in Java with functionalities like adding, viewing, issuing, and returning books.

tasks.description: Setup Your Project Structure in the Library Management System project.

steps.description: Create a file named LibrarySystem.java with the main method.
guidelines: Use a public class named LibrarySystem.
Include the main method as the entry point.
why: This sets up the foundation of your Java project.

steps.description: Import essential Java packages.
guidelines: Use Scanner for input collection.
Use ArrayList to store book objects.
why: Imports are necessary to use standard Java utilities.
steps.starting_code: // import java.util.*;
steps.final_code:
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.Scanner;

tasks.description: Create the Book Class in the Library Management System project.

steps.description: Create a Book class with fields like id, title, author, and isIssued.
guidelines: Make the fields public or use private with a constructor.
Use boolean for issue status.
why: Models each book in the system as an object.

tasks.description: Setup the Book Inventory in the Library Management System project.

steps.description: Use an ArrayList to store books.
guidelines: Declare it as a static field in LibrarySystem.
why: Stores all books dynamically.
steps.starting_code: // static ArrayList<Book> books;
steps.final_code: static ArrayList<Book> books = new ArrayList<>();

steps.description: Manually insert a few books to test the system.
guidelines: Use the constructor to create book objects and add to list.
why: Useful for testing before full interaction is implemented.
steps.starting_code: // books.add(new Book(...));
steps.final_code:
books.add(new Book(1, "1984", "George Orwell"));
books.add(new Book(2, "The Hobbit", "J.R.R. Tolkien"));

tasks.description: Add Book Functionality in the Library Management System project.

steps.description: Ask the user for book id, title, and author.
guidelines: Use Scanner to input id, title, author.
Use nextLine() after nextInt().
why: Gets user data for creating book entries.
steps.starting_code: // Input book fields

steps.description: Create and add the new Book object to the inventory list.
guidelines: Use constructor and add() method.
why: Stores the user-provided book into your system.
steps.starting_code: // books.add(new Book(...));
steps.final_code:
books.add(new Book(id, title, author));
System.out.println("Book added successfully!");

tasks.description: View All Books in the Library Management System project.

steps.description: Print all the book details in the list.
guidelines: Use an enhanced for-loop to iterate and print.
why: Displays current inventory.
steps.starting_code: // for (Book book : books)

tasks.description: Issue a Book in the Library Management System project.

steps.description: Check list to find the book and issue it if available.
guidelines: Loop through books, compare ID and check isIssued.
why: Lets user borrow a book.
steps.starting_code: // if (book.id == id && !book.isIssued)

tasks.description: Return a Book in the Library Management System project.

steps.description: Set isIssued to false for the returned book.
guidelines: Find book by ID and ensure it's currently issued.
why: Lets users return books they've borrowed.
steps.starting_code: // if (book.id == id && book.isIssued)

tasks.description: Add Menu System in the Library Management System project.

steps.description: Provide options and call methods accordingly.
guidelines: Use while(true) and switch statement for user interaction.
why: Provides easy navigation for users.
steps.starting_code: // menu with options 1-5

projects.description: Build a secure console-based banking app in Java to manage accounts, deposits, withdrawals, and balance inquiries.

tasks.description: Setup Project Structure in the Bank Management System project.

steps.description: Create the main class BankSystem with a main method.
guidelines: Create a file BankSystem.java.
Add the main method for execution.

steps.description: Add required Java imports like Scanner and ArrayList.
guidelines: Import java.util.Scanner and java.util.ArrayList.
why: To enable input and store multiple accounts.

import java.util.Scanner;
import java.util.ArrayList;

tasks.description: Create Account Class in the Bank Management System project.

steps.description: Create fields for account number, name, and balance.
guidelines: Use int for account number, String for name, and double for balance.

steps.description: Add a constructor and getter methods for the fields.
guidelines: Initialize fields through the constructor.
Provide public getter methods.
why: Encapsulates and accesses data safely.

steps.description: Use ArrayList<Account> to store all account objects.
guidelines: Declare and initialize the list globally.
why: Stores all created accounts in memory.

steps.final_code: static ArrayList<Account> accounts = new ArrayList<>();

guidelines: Create an account object and add to list.
why: Facilitates testing without user input.
steps.starting_code: // accounts.add(...)

tasks.description: Create New Account in the Bank Management System project.

steps.description: Prompt user for account number, name, and initial balance.
guidelines: Use Scanner for all inputs.
why: Interactive user account creation.
steps.starting_code: // collect input

steps.description: Create a new account and add it to the ArrayList.
guidelines: Instantiate Account and call add().
why: Adds the user-created account to system.
steps.starting_code: // add to accounts
steps.final_code:
accounts.add(new Account(accNo, name, balance));
System.out.println("Account created successfully.");

tasks.description: Deposit Money in the Bank Management System project.

steps.description: Find account from list by number.
guidelines: Loop through ArrayList and match account number.
why: You must locate account before modifying.
steps.starting_code: // if (acc.getAccountNumber() == accNo)

steps.description: Add deposit amount to account's balance.
guidelines: Use a setter or modify directly inside Account class.
why: Implements deposit feature.
steps.starting_code: // acc.deposit(amount);
steps.final_code: acc.deposit(amount); // inside Account class: balance += amount;

tasks.description: Withdraw Money in the Bank Management System project.

steps.description: Ensure user has enough balance.
guidelines: Compare balance before subtracting amount.
why: Prevents overdraft errors.
steps.starting_code: // if (balance >= amount)

tasks.description: View Account Details in the Bank Management System project.

steps.description: Show name, account number, and balance.
guidelines: Use getters to print details.
why: Lets user confirm account state.

tasks.description: Create Main Menu in the Bank Management System project.

steps.description: Show menu options in loop and switch.
guidelines: Use while(true) with switch case.
why: Provides user with navigation control.
steps.starting_code: // while loop for menu

projects.description: Build a Java app that fetches and displays real-time weather data from an external API.

String apiKey = "your_api_key";
String urlString = "https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?q=" + city + "&appid=" + apiKey + "&units=metric";

steps.description: Check response code and handle exceptions.
guidelines: Use try-catch or validate response code.
why: Avoids crash and improves UX.

tasks.description: Create a Menu Loop in the Weather App project.

steps.description: Allow the user to check multiple cities in one session.
guidelines: Use while loop and prompt user for next city.
why: Improves experience and interactivity.

projects.description: Create a robust Java weather application that supports search history, multi-day forecasts, unit conversion, and enhanced error handling using external APIs.

tasks.description: Initialize Project in the Advanced Weather App project.

steps.description: Create the AdvancedWeatherApp.java file with a main method.
guidelines: Initialize the main class and display a welcome message.
why: Sets up the project entry point.

steps.description: Import all Java utility and networking packages required.
guidelines: Include java.net.*, java.io.*, org.json.*, java.util.*
why: Necessary for HTTP requests and JSON parsing.

tasks.description: Get User Input in the Advanced Weather App project.

steps.description: Prompt the user for the city name and units (Celsius/Fahrenheit).
guidelines: Use Scanner to read inputs and save both values.
why: Dynamic user control over units and location.
steps.starting_code: // Scanner input for city and unit

steps.description: Store each search in a list for history feature.
guidelines: Use ArrayList to collect each searched city.
why: Track user searches for future reference.

history.add(city);

tasks.description: Construct API URL in the Advanced Weather App project.

steps.description: Build the URL string with city and units.
guidelines: Include API key and user-selected units.
why: Enables parameterized API requests.
steps.starting_code: // String url = ...
steps.final_code:
String apiKey = "your_api_key";
String url = "https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?q=" + city + "&appid=" + apiKey + "&units=" + units;

guidelines: Navigate through 'main' JSON object.
why: Displays core weather data to user.
steps.starting_code: // JSONObject obj = ...

steps.description: Extract 'description' from weather array.
guidelines: Access first object of 'weather' array.
why: Gives user readable weather status.
steps.starting_code: // String desc = ...
steps.final_code:
JSONObject weather = obj.getJSONArray("weather").getJSONObject(0);
String description = weather.getString("description");

tasks.description: Display Weather Information in the Advanced Weather App project.

steps.description: Display weather data clearly with labels.

why: Presents weather details to user.

guidelines: Catch IOException and JSONException separately.
why: Handles runtime failures gracefully.
